conclusion: The triangle ABC is equilateral with side length L.
BC is the diameter of the attached hemispherical part whose center is O; radius R = L/2.
The incident light is a horizontal parallel beam parallel to BC that strikes the side AB.
The angle of incidence on AB is i = 30°.
Let the refractive index of the glass be n, with n_air = 1.
sin r = sin i / n = 1/2n.
The refracted ray inside the triangle makes the angle φ = -30° + r with the +X-axis.
Adopt coordinates with B(-L/2,0), C(+L/2,0) and A(0,√3 L/2).
Let s be the distance from B along AB (0 ≤ s ≤ L).
A ray launched from the point P(x_P,y_P) = (-L/2+s/2, √3/2 s) travels in the direction (cos φ, sin φ) and meets the line BC (y=0) at x = x_P - y_P/tan φ.
The last ray that just reaches the right end C(x=L/2) comes from the point D for which s=BD=L/4.
Requiring x=L/2 leads to tan φ = -√3/7.
Insert φ = -30° + r and use tan(r-30°) = (tan r - 1/√3)/(1 + tan r 1/√3); solving gives tan r = √3/6, sin r = 1/√13.
Combine with sin r = 1/2n ⟹ n = √13/2.
Speed of light in the hemisphere v = c/n = 2c/√13.
The greatest possible straight-line distance a refracted ray can cover inside the hemisphere is its diameter, i.e., the path from B straight across to C: ℓ_max = BC = L.
Longest propagation time t_max = ℓ_max/v = L/2c √13.
With the numerical hint √13 ≈ 3.6.
t_max = √13/2 L/c (about 1.8 L/c).
The refracted light that travels the full diameter of the hemisphere takes √13/2 L/c seconds to traverse it.
